{"comments": {"id": 27386, "count": 37, "talk_id": 2794}, "threadId": 27386, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "2794", "description": "For a crime he committed in his early twenties, the courts sentenced Marlon Peterson to 10 years in prison -- and, as he says, a lifetime of irrelevance. While behind bars, Peterson found redemption through a penpal mentorship program with students from Brooklyn. In this brave talk, he reminds us why we should invest in the humanity of those people society would like to disregard and discard.", "event": "TED Residency", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Marlon Peterson: Am I not human? A call for criminal justice reform", "slug": "marlon_peterson_am_i_not_human_a_call_for_criminal_justice_reform", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "3186", "slug": "marlon_peterson", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Marlon", "lastname": "Peterson", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Human justice advocate", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/a17c18a8ec9a012350524f88971469b1f8312e48_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Marlon Peterson is a writer, youth development expert and human justice advocate.", "whylisten": "

Marlon Peterson is the host of the podcast, Decarcerated, which highlights the journeys of resilience, redemption and success of formerly incarcerated people.

Since his release from prison in 2009, after serving 10 years, Peterson has spearheaded the creation of two youth development programs in New York City, How Our Lives Link Altogether (H.O.L.L.A!) and Youth Organizing to Save Our Streets (YO SOS). With a focus on gun violence prevention and youth advocacy, both programs have provided programming for hundreds of young people.

In 2015 Peterson left his full-time work in the nonprofit sector to create The Precedential Group, a social justice consultancy that works to address the trauma revolving around the intersections of race, gender, violence, police violence and community violence. His work through the Precedential Group has allowed him to provide support for organizations throughout the United States and Trinidad & Tobago, W.I.

As a writer, advocate, program developer and public speaker Peterson has been recognized as a Soros Justice Fellow, Aspen Ideas Festival Scholar, Ebony Magazine Power 100 Honoree and TED Resident. His writings have appeared and been cited in The Nation, Gawker, The Atlantic, Huff Post, Black Press USA, Ebony and the Trinidad & Tobago Guardian. He has contributed to Kiese Laymon's aaward-winning novel, How to Slowly Kill Yourself and Others in America and Love Lives Here, Too by former New York Times columnist, Sheila Rule.

Peterson is Brooklyn born and bred with a Trinidadian heart. He is a graduate of New York University and is currently working on his first Pulitzer, a memoir.

This collection of essays speaks to the complications, vulnerabilities, and trauma of living and surviving in America. Grappling with the intersections of race, gender, violence, and love, Kiese prioritizes personal narratives in describing the many touch points of hurt that informs the harm of growing up in America.", "note": "Kiese Laymon Agate Bolden, 2013", "link_url": "https://www.amazon.com/Slowly-Kill-Yourself-Others-America/dp/1932841776/ref=as_li_tf_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=0520271440&linkCode=as2&tag=teco06-20", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "READ_Book", "headline": "*Frankenstein*", "blurb": "An international classic, I did not expect to connect to this book. For beginners, I thought Frankenstein was the Monster, but quickly learned that Dr. Frankenstein created this being that society conditioned into a "Monster." The trampling of the Monster’s need for relevance by his community can be paralleled to how many poor people in marginalized communities experience life—seeking to matter and succumbing to the boot of expected oppression.", "note": "Mary Shelley AmazonClassics, 2017", "link_url": "https://www.amazon.com/Frankenstein-AmazonClassics-Mary-Shelley/dp/1542046157/ref=as_li_tf_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=0520271440&linkCode=as2&tag=teco06-20", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "READ_Book", "headline": "*Bridge to Brilliance*", "blurb": "Dr. Nadia Lopez's journey of creating a wholesome learning environment in one of America’s most under-resourced communities, Brownsville, Brooklyn is inspiring. As the founding principal of a middle school in a crime-ridden/crime-expectant community, this book underscores the importance of seeing greatness in people even when they are unable to see it in themselves.", "note": "Nadia Lopez Viking, 2016", "link_url": "https://www.amazon.com/Bridge-Brilliance-Principal-Community-Inspiring/dp/1101980257/ref=as_li_tf_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=0520271440&linkCode=as2&tag=teco06-20", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "READ_Book", "headline": "*I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings*", "blurb": "Maya Angelou is brilliant.  We all know that. This book takes you inside the mind of a young poor Black girl experiencing trauma and violence. It also pushes us to admire the immense resilience of young people.  ", "note": "Maya Angelou", "link_url": "https://www.amazon.com/Know-Why-Caged-Bird-Sings/dp/0345514408/ref=as_li_tf_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=0520271440&linkCode=as2&tag=teco06-20", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "LISTEN", "headline": "NPR Interview: Baz Dreisinger", "blurb": "Describing the steeple of Trinidad & Tobago, Dr. Kim Johnson of the Trinidad Carnival Institute says, "It was, perhaps, like rock and roll in the U.S. It came here and overnight every young person was in it." This NPR interview with Dr. Baz Dreisinger highlights the journey of the only acoustic instrument created in the 20th century. According to Dr. Dreisinger, "This kind of creativity—turning trash into something beautiful—is what history is all about."", "note": "", "link_url": "", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "READ_Article", "headline": "Q&A: Zones Where No One Has Guns—Not Even the Police, Open Society Foundations and Marlon Peterson", "blurb": "The idea that we can live in productive and safe communities that are not overly reliant on law enforcement is possible, In this interview with the Open Society Foundation, I outlay why I believe we should invest more in communities and less in law enforcement. ", "note": "", "link_url": "https://www.opensocietyfoundations.org/voices/zones-where-no-one-has-guns-not-even-police", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "READ_Book", "headline": "", "blurb": "", "note": "", "link_url": "", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}]}]}, "more_resources": [{"status": "approved", "headline": "TED Residency", "blurb": "The TED Residency is an incubator for breakthrough ideas. "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Human justice advocate", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/a17c18a8ec9a012350524f88971469b1f8312e48_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Marlon Peterson is a writer, youth development expert and human justice advocate.", "whylisten": "

Marlon Peterson is the host of the podcast, Decarcerated, which highlights the journeys of resilience, redemption and success of formerly incarcerated people.

Since his release from prison in 2009, after serving 10 years, Peterson has spearheaded the creation of two youth development programs in New York City, How Our Lives Link Altogether (H.O.L.L.A!) and Youth Organizing to Save Our Streets (YO SOS). With a focus on gun violence prevention and youth advocacy, both programs have provided programming for hundreds of young people.

In 2015 Peterson left his full-time work in the nonprofit sector to create The Precedential Group, a social justice consultancy that works to address the trauma revolving around the intersections of race, gender, violence, police violence and community violence. His work through the Precedential Group has allowed him to provide support for organizations throughout the United States and Trinidad & Tobago, W.I.

As a writer, advocate, program developer and public speaker Peterson has been recognized as a Soros Justice Fellow, Aspen Ideas Festival Scholar, Ebony Magazine Power 100 Honoree and TED Resident. His writings have appeared and been cited in The Nation, Gawker, The Atlantic, Huff Post, Black Press USA, Ebony and the Trinidad & Tobago Guardian. He has contributed to Kiese Laymon's aaward-winning novel, How to Slowly Kill Yourself and Others in America and Love Lives Here, Too by former New York Times columnist, Sheila Rule.

Peterson is Brooklyn born and bred with a Trinidadian heart. He is a graduate of New York University and is currently working on his first Pulitzer, a memoir.

title: Am I not human? A call for criminal justice reform
